question.title: Employee Bonus
question.content:
Select all employee's name and bonus whose bonus is < 1000.


Table:Employee

+-------+--------+-----------+--------+
| empId |  name  | supervisor| salary |
+-------+--------+-----------+--------+
|   1   | John   |  3        | 1000      |
|   2   | Dan    |  3        | 2000      |
|   3   | Brad   |  null     | 4000     |
|   4   | Thomas |  3        | 4000   |
+-------+--------+-----------+--------+


  • empId is the primary key column for this table.


    Table: Bonus

    +-------+-------+
| empId | bonus |
+-------+-------+
| 2     | 500   |
| 4     | 2000  |
+-------+-------+


  • empId is the primary key column for this table.


    Example output:
     +-------+-------+
 | name  | bonus |
+-------+-------+
| Dan    | 500 |
| John   |          |
| Brad   |         |
+-------+-------+

rephrased.body: Given two tables, `Employee` and `Bonus`, write a SQL query to select the name of each employee and their corresponding bonus.  Only include employees whose bonus is less than 1000. If an employee does not have a bonus record, their bonus should be represented as NULL.
constraints: empId is the primary key column for the Employee table.
empId is the primary key column for the Bonus table.

testcases.explanation: John and Brad are included because they do not have bonus records.  Thomas is excluded because his bonus is 2000, which is not less than 1000. Dan's bonus is 500, which is less than 1000.

If an employee doesn't exist in the Employee table with a corresponding empId in the Bonus table and bonus < 1000, no record will appear for them in the final output. Similarly, if the tables are empty, then the output will be empty as well.
